text: need help known problem: found relevant thread nat-user google group: please reply . found GitHub issue: please reply details just like (click emoji button add thumbs ) let us know ’re trouble . ’ll need GitHub login . ’re sure: ask new question nat-user google group linking found.

Read Get help! section tidyverse site information. Thanks help!

title: FAFB-FlyWire
text: articles gives quick overview mapping points FAFB14 (used “walled garden” Virtual Fly Brain FlyWire.
code: library(fafbseg) #> Run dr_fafbseg() for a status report on your installation

title: FAFB-FlyWire
text: known points Compare displacements (nm) forward inverse mapping sample neuron. First map points stats quick histogram
code: # identified location in FAFB14 p.fafb.nm <- cbind(477042, 284535, 90680) p.fafb.raw <- p.fafb.nm/c(4,4,40) # corresponding location in FlyWire p.flywire.raw <- cbind(118865, 71338, 2267) p.flywire.nm <- p.flywire.raw * c(4,4,40) # check displacement flywire2fafb(p.flywire.nm)-p.fafb.nm #>      X  Y Z #> [1,] 3 -1 0  # check what happens when you apply the inverse fafb2flywire(p.fafb.nm)-p.flywire.nm #>       X Y Z #> [1,] -3 2 0 data("AV4b1", package='catmaid') before=xyzmatrix(AV4b1) after=fafb2flywire(before) d=sqrt(rowSums((before-after)^2)) summary(d) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>     2.0   287.9   416.0   446.9   559.1  2113.7 hist(d, br=20, main='Displacement /µm') sample_points_in_surf <- function(x, n){   x=as.mesh3d(x)   bb=boundingbox(x)   mm=mapply(runif, min=bb[1,], max=bb[2,], n = n)   colnames(mm)=c("X","Y","Z")   data.frame(mm, inside=pointsinside(mm,x)) } set.seed(42) sxyz=sample_points_in_surf(FAFB14.surf,25000) sxyz.in=subset(sxyz, inside) sxyz.fw=fafb2flywire(xyzmatrix(sxyz.in)) deltas=sxyz.fw-sxyz.in delta=rowSums(deltas[,c("X","Y")]) jet.colors<-colorRampPalette(c('navy','cyan','yellow','red')) nclear3d(); spheres3d(xyzmatrix(sxyz.in), col=jet.colors(10)[cut(delta, breaks = 10)], rad=2000)

title: FAFB-FlyWire
text: Let’s send points back
code: sxyz.fafb2=flywire2fafb(sxyz.fw) deltas=sxyz.fafb2-xyzmatrix(sxyz.in) delta=rowSums(deltas[,c("X","Y")]) hist(delta, main = "Round Trip Error", xlab='delta /nm')

title: FAFB-FlyWire
text: map complex objects, use xform_brain()  Note relevant links: Load flywire mesh plot CATMAID skeleton
code: AV4b1.fw=xform_brain(AV4b1, sample='FAFB14', reference = 'FlyWire') # find the main branch point of a neuron, a good place to point to mainbranch <- function(x, ...) {   if(is.neuronlist(x))      return(nlapply(x, mainbranch, ...))      sx=nat::simplify_neuron(x, ...)   xyzmatrix(sx)[sx$BranchPoints,] } choose_segmentation("flywire") open_fafb_ngl(mainbranch(AV4b1.fw), coords.only = TRUE) #> [1] "88371.25,40478.75,3668" av4.fwm=read_cloudvolume_meshes('720575940618054533') nclear3d() plot3d(AV4b1.fw, col='red', lwd=3) wire3d(av4.fwm[[1]], col='grey', alpha=.2)

title: Accessing the chunked graph server
text: set programmatic access FlyWire, use flywire_set_token() follows: follow -screen prompts.
code: library(fafbseg) flywire_set_token()

title: Accessing the chunked graph server
text: main goal connectomics trace (segment) branching morphology neurons 3D volume (typically based electron microscopy) identify connections (synapses) together define connectome. Neuron segmentation can either skeleton-based (centre line defining part neuronal arbour traced ) voxel-based, filled 3D structure defined labelling every voxel integer id, representing membership particular object; typically displayed 3D mesh surface. Although skeleton-based segmentation efficient manual segmentation humans, voxel-wise segmentation natural machine learning algorithms. Furthermore, generates richer representation neuron (capturing structural features) , crucially, also resolves ambiguities object identity. example two users manually trace neuron skeleton, place nodes different positions trivial computationally determine part object join tracing independent pieces together. contrast voxel-wise segmentation every xyz location image explicitly defined part specified object. voxel-wise segmentation, neuron can considered collection voxels grouped together connected components. Machine learning based algorithms try identify connected components (e.g. using flood filling networks). However machines perfect many segments wrongly connected. Hence need step humans proofread segments alters connections. connected components can readily represented vertices connections edges. human observer essentially modifies edges graph structure. Note graph representation object segmentation distinct binary tree represents neuronal morphology connection graph neurons within neural network. graph based representation segmentation also advantages synchronous editing, can major technical issue many users generate proof-read segmentation time. CATMAID web application (skeleton based tracing) approaches allowing multiple users edit neurons using shared database. implementation reduces conflicts simple expedient allowing users see ’s work real time. However explicit merge step needed conflicting annotations created (usually editing happened different database) can computationally complex. Seung Lab developed data structure system called chunked graph lets users modify segmentations (3D voxel-wise) real-time allows access earlier versions segmentation. brief overview system published medium. practice initial -segmentation generated, consisting many “supervoxels”. supervoxels, small collections perhaps tens thousands individual voxels, effectively immutable almost certain belong object. supervoxels leaves graph database representation segmented objects. use supervoxels reduces size graph database compared situation individual voxel represented. long human proof-reading based base segmentation, strategies merge proof-reading even happens asynchronously. However merging proof-reading based different base segmentations defined different underlying supervoxels still complex; similar challenge exists necessary map proof-reading based one base segmentation newer (presumably improved) base segmentation.

title: Accessing the chunked graph server
text: One goals fafbseg package provide access different 3D segmentations FAFB dataset. Currently available segmentations include FlyWire (based 3D CNNs : U-Net) GoogleBrain (based recursive CNNs : flood-filling networks). Furthermore enable location transfer comparison CATMAID (skeleton based) manual reconstruction. order achieve one needs access 3D segmentations stored graph database Graphene/PyChunkedGraph. also provide Python tool called CloudVolume provides programmatic access graph database.

title: Accessing the chunked graph server
text: gain access Graphene/Chunkedgraph server using token granted authenticate via Google account. simplest way offer open browser, generate new token save standard location. Note invalidate previous token!
code: library(fafbseg) flywire_set_token()

title: Accessing the chunked graph server
text: manual steps flywire_set_token() tries automate follows Visit https://globalv1.flywire-daf.com/auth/api/v1/refresh_token, Copy token present , let’s say "xxyyzz" create file named cave-secret.json location ~/.cloudvolume/secrets/cave-secret.json. example, Terminal: Paste following contents Save file Now access chunked graph server
code: mkdir -p .cloudvolume/secrets/ touch ~/.cloudvolume/secrets/cave-secret.json open ~/.cloudvolume/secrets/cave-secret.json -e {   "token": "xxyyzz" }

title: Capturing neuroglancer meshes from a browser scene
text: Originally fafbseg support reading objects directly neuroglancer scene URL. approach capture interactive web session. Things moved ability read meshes directly brainmaps API via read_brainmaps_meshes() using CloudVolume interface via read_cloudvolume_meshes(). However information retained reference might helpful direct mesh retrieval yet available.

title: Capturing neuroglancer meshes from a browser scene
text: make sure one neuron displayed want parse object identifier relationships. Chrome can generate appropriate set curl download commands : Opening Chrome Developer console (View … Developer … JavaScript Console), (re)loading page interest selecting network tab selecting downloaded object right clicking choosing (Copy … Copy cURL). can either save contents clipboard text file (e.g.  all_curl.sh) just keep clipboard. can go R proceed follows
code: library(fafbseg) # omit the first argument if you want to use the clipboard fetch_all_curl("all_curl.sh", outdir="alldata",   regex="brainmaps.googleapis.com", fixed=TRUE) meshdata=read_ng_dump("alldata") library(elmr) # or whatever your CATMAID neuron skid is y=read.neuron.catmaid(23432) compare_ng_neuron(meshdata, y)

title: fafbseg-catmaid-legacy-info
text: can use package generate URLs pointing defined location neuroglancer dataset. includes arbitrary locations FAFB dataset specified interactively using CATMAID URLs. example, find location referenced tweet: Zoom @dddavi whole fly brain EM dataset using public @catmaid server hosted @virtualflybrain. whole brain view synaptic detail. Click explore location within mushroom body parallel fibre system ! https://t.co/JxsBGe3RbJ @flyconnectome pic.twitter.com/NfDiXgJOPX can use approach https://flywire.ai URLs additional option transforming coordinates get closer correct location FlyWire assembly FAFB data (typically hundred nm ). See flywire2fafb() details.
code: library(fafbseg) # First, optionally set a package option with an example neuroglancer URL for your dataset. # This URL will define the image layers that are visible. You need to use an # URL for which you have access. The package ships with a default using segmentation # fafb_v14:fafb_v14_16nm_v00c_split3xfill2 which is probably what you need. options(fafbseg.sampleurl="https://<neuroglancerlurl>")  # Now open location specified by CATMAID URL u='https://fafb.catmaid.virtualflybrain.org/?pid=2&zp=131280&yp=170014.98879622458&xp=426584.81386896875&tool=navigator&sid0=2&s0=-1' open_fafb_ngl(u)  # or display raw coordinates that you can paste into active Neuroglancer session open_fafb_ngl(u, coords.only = TRUE) # opens a new browser tab with_segmentation('flywire31',    open_fafb_ngl(u, sample = 'FAFB14', reference = "FlyWire"))  # writes coordinates to clipboard so that you can paste them into an existings # flywire neuroglancer browser tab with_segmentation('flywire31',    clipr::write_clip(     open_fafb_ngl(u, coords.only = TRUE,        sample = 'FAFB14', reference = "FlyWire")))

title: fafbseg-catmaid-legacy-info
text: can also go opposite direction convert neuroglancer location CATMAID URL. neuroglancer location can come either URL JSON scene specification obtained clicking {} icon.
code: # round trip using the CATMAID URL we used earlier ngu = open_fafb_ngl(u, open = FALSE)  # now open using elmr package - installed like so if necessary:  # natmanager::install(pkgs="natverse/elmr") elmr::open_fafb(ngl_decode_scene(ngu))

title: fafbseg-catmaid-legacy-info
text: package now includes simple Shiny application translates two URL schemes. can use online version app https://jefferislab.shinyapps.io/CATMAID-Neuroglancer-Converter/ download GitHub run locally latest version app: Currently application convert FlyWire<->FAFB coordinates, relatively simple addition using flywire2fafb().
code: if (!require("shiny")) install.packages("shiny") shiny::runGitHub("natverse/fafbseg", subdir = "inst/app/")

title: fafbseg-catmaid-legacy-info
text: Currently package provides functionality read neuroglancer meshes R compare meshes traced neuron objects e.g. CATMAID. need authenticate appropriate API. Alternatively see article Capturing neuroglancer meshes browser scene. can read meshes FlyWire segmentation FAFB (roughly) can read meshes Google brain segmentation FAFB (roughly)
code: choose_segmentation(release = 'flywire31') open_fafb_ngl(c(109459, 41305, 5424)*c(4,4,40)) va6pn=read_cloudvolume_meshes("720575940633169983") # compare with VFB CATMAID library(elmr) va6pn.skel=read.neurons.catmaid("name:VA6.*PN") # let's take a look at those plot3d(va6pn, col='grey', lwd=0.5, type='wire') # only plot first neuron on RHS plot3d(va6pn.skel[1], lwd=3, col='red')  # can also transform the FAFB14 skeleton from VFB to FlyWire coordinates va6pn.skel.fw <- xform_brain(va6pn.skel[1], reference = 'FlyWire', sample='FAFB14') nclear3d() plot3d(va6pn, col='grey', lwd=0.5, type='wire') # only plot first neuron on RHS plot3d(va6pn.skel.fw, lwd=3, col='red') choose_segmentation(release = '20190805') open_fafb_ngl(c(109459, 41305, 5424)*c(4,4,40)) va6pn=read_brainmaps_meshes("710435991")

title: Installing python modules: cloudvolume, meshparty and skeletor
text: Download miniconda install , includes conda, python, basic packages, including pip: Make sure know install (e.g. usually : /opt/miniconda3), update recent version Terminal: $ conda update conda Hit ‘y’ proceed prompted. default python /opt/miniconda3/bin/python, can check $ python

title: Installing python modules: cloudvolume, meshparty and skeletor
text: Use conda create activate environment can install everything need: (deactivate active environment, use $ conda deactivate flywire_env) point environment can use conda install <package_name> simply anything ’s available , pip also install packages environment, unless PATH variable bash.profile file tells otherwise. Check pip default: $ pip give something miniconda folder, like /opt/miniconda3/envs/flywire_env/bin/pip. However, might system python’s pip. can comment PATH variable python .bash.profile running: $ touch ~/.bash_profile; open ~/.bash_profile adding # lines PATH="/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/bin:${PATH}" export PATH. pip return right thing, thing applies python. Alternatively can always specify terminal pip want use, suboptimal (e.g. /opt/miniconda3/envs/flywire_env/bin/pip install cloud-volume).
code: $ conda create --name flywire_env python=3.7 $ conda activate flywire_env $ conda install nomkl

title: Installing python modules: cloudvolume, meshparty and skeletor
text: Now can install cloud-volume $ pip install cloud-volume need compiler (XCode Mac) install everything. don’t XCode, either need update OSX recent version download AppStore, can get version compatible current system : https://developer.apple.com/support/xcode/ tried installing Windows, try get right compiler help Google. thread FlyWire Slack might find useful things. use cloud-volume, need get token authorisation : https://globalv1.flywire-daf.com/auth/api/v1/refresh_token, add .json file create location: ~/.cloudvolume/secrets/cave-secret.json, see help .

title: Installing python modules: cloudvolume, meshparty and skeletor
text: Install meshparty: $ pip install meshparty errored failure install dependency: pykdtree clang: error: unsupported option '-fopenmp'. issue C++ compiler version (probably), good thing ’re using conda now can : $ conda install -c conda-forge pykdtree pip installing meshparty worked fine previous command. Now meshparty cloud-volume environment, meshparty optional dependencies skeletonisation, need install: order use meshparty_skeletonisation also install PyChunkedGraph, dependency called igneous, Seung lab. Install igneous GitHub, pip install PyChunkedGraph:
code: $ conda install -c conda-forge pyembree $ pip install caveclient $ git clone git@github.com:seung-lab/igneous.git $ cd igneous $ pip install -r requirements.txt $ python setup.py develop $ pip install PyChunkedGraph

title: Installing python modules: cloudvolume, meshparty and skeletor
text: want use packages R reticulate natverse fafbseg functions objects need package reticulate R (install.packages("reticulate")) tell use python version conda environment. Run R console:usethis::edit_r_environ() add line RETICULATE_PYTHON="/opt/miniconda3/envs/flywire_env/bin/python" path python conda environment. sure leave blank line end file. Restart R session, load reticulate fafbseg (necessary install/update remotes::install_github("jefferis/fafbseg"). Check python version reticulate::py_config(), show path gave RETICULATE_PYTHON variable. possible RStudio session crash reticulate::py_config(). may multiple copies OpenMP runtime linked program. dangerous, since can degrade performance cause incorrect results. fix, try:
code: $ conda uninstall numpy scikit-learn $ conda install nomkl numpy scikit-learn $ conda remove mkl mkl-service

title: Installing python modules: cloudvolume, meshparty and skeletor
text: Let’s set R look write flywire data. need access production node flywire environment (.e. passed test). Use usethis::edit_r_profile, R profile add: GJ: Don’t . Just use choose_segmentation("flywire") able read meshes, skeletonise , plot FAFB:
code: # Production flywire options(fafbseg.cloudvolume.url='graphene://https://prodv1.flywire-daf.com/segmentation/1.0/fly_v31') # Load packages library(natverse) library(fafbseg) choose_segmentation("flywire") dir.create("flywire_skeletons")  # Points in FAFBv14 (nm) to flywire coordinates (also nm) points = matrix(c(723086,200499,90960),ncol=3) flywire.fafb = xform_brain(points, sample='FAFB14', ref="FlyWire")  # Get mesh id = flywire_xyz2id(flywire.fafb) neuron_mesh = read_cloudvolume_meshes(id)  # Skeletonise mesh meshparty_skeletonize(id, savedir = "flywire_skeletons") neuron_skel <- read.neuron.swc(sprintf("flywire_skeletons/%s.swc",id))  nopen3d() plot3d(FAFB, alpha = 0.1) plot3d(neuron_skel*1000, WithNodes = F, col = "red", lwd = 2) wire3d(neuron_mesh[[1]], col = "cyan", alpha = 0.2)

title: Installing python modules: cloudvolume, meshparty and skeletor
text: may also want install skeletor, package Philipp Schlegel helps thin skeletonise meshes . can produce accurate results get using TEASAR meshparty, depend either. install, : test skeletor works flywire neurons python using: installed skeletor specified python environment described , R able :
code: $ source activate flywire_env $ conda install nomkl $ pip3 install git+git://github.com/schlegelp/skeletor@master $ pip3 install fastremap $ pip3 install ncollpyde python from cloudvolume import CloudVolume import trimesh as tm import skeletor as sk id=720575940614134045 id=720575940634367221 vol = CloudVolume('graphene://https://prodv1.flywire-daf.com/segmentation/1.0/fly_v31', use_https=True) m = vol.mesh.get(id, deduplicate_chunk_boundaries=False)[id] m = tm.Trimesh(m.vertices, m.faces) simp = sk.pre.simplify(m, ratio=.1) cntr = sk.pre.contract(simp, SL=10, WH0=2, iter_lim=4, epsilon=0.05, precision=1e-6, progress=False, operator='umbrella') swc = sk.skeletonize.by_vertex_clusters(cntr, sampling_dist=500, progress=False) swc = sk.post.clean_up(s = swc, mesh = simp, theta = 0.01) sk.post.radii(s = swc, mesh = simp, method='knn', n=5, aggregate='mean') print(swc)  # Faster, wavefront skeletonisation m = sk.pre.fix_mesh(m, remove_disconnected=10) swc2 = sk.skeletonize.by_wavefront(m, waves=2s) print(swc2) # Skeletonise choose_segmentation("flywire") nx=xform_brain(elmr::dense_core_neurons, ref="FlyWire", sample="FAFB14") xyz =xyzmatrix(nx) ids = unique(flywire_xyz2id(xyz[sample(1:nrow(xyz),100),])) neurons = skeletor(ids)  # Plot in 3D nopen3d() plot3d(neurons) # note, in flywire space, slightly different to FAFBv14 space plot3d(nx, col="black", lwd  =2) # note, in flywire space

title: Mesh to mesh distances
text: two ways can immediately think addressing Find distance every vertex mesh 1 nearest neighbour mesh 2 Find (signed) distance every vertex mesh 1 surface mesh 2 Obviously ideal situation find mesh mesh distances two objects (even Euclidean distance transform voxel representation objects.) neither accessible. Option 1 probably still perfectly good option purposes since meshes quite densely sampled (.e. vertices close together).

title: Mesh to mesh distances
text: Let’s use example mentioned FlyWire slack. asked find volume mesh. first attempt fails need clean mesh:
code: library(fafbseg) ## Loading required package: nat ## Loading required package: rgl ## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'nat': ##   method             from ##   as.mesh3d.ashape3d rgl ## Some nat functions depend on a CMTK installation. See ?cmtk and README.md for details. ##  ## Attaching package: 'nat' ## The following object is masked from 'package:rgl': ##  ##     wire3d ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ##  ##     intersect, setdiff, union ## Run dr_fafbseg() for a status report on your installation choose_segmentation("flywire31") va6pn=read_cloudvolume_meshes("720575940633169983") ##   downloading meshes ##   parsing downloaded meshes Rvcg::vcgVolume(va6pn[[1]]) va6pn.clean=Rvcg::vcgClean(va6pn[[1]], sel=0:6, iterate = T) ## removed 68 duplicate faces and 0 duplicate vertices ## removed 0 unreferenced vertices ## removed 34 Non-manifold faces ## removed 0 degenerate faces ## removed 16 Non-manifold vertices ## split 3 non-manifold vertices ## merged 0 close vertices ## removed 0 duplicate faces and 0 duplicate vertices ## removed 3 unreferenced vertices ## removed 0 Non-manifold faces ## removed 0 degenerate faces ## removed 3 Non-manifold vertices ## split 0 non-manifold vertices ## merged 0 close vertices ## removed 0 duplicate faces and 0 duplicate vertices ## removed 0 unreferenced vertices ## removed 0 Non-manifold faces ## removed 0 degenerate faces ## removed 0 Non-manifold vertices ## split 0 non-manifold vertices ## merged 0 close vertices vol=Rvcg::vcgVolume(va6pn.clean) ## Warning in Rvcg::vcgVolume(va6pn.clean): Mesh is not watertight! USE RESULT ## WITH CARE! ## Warning in Rvcg::vcgVolume(va6pn.clean): Mesh is not coherently oriented! USE ## RESULT WITH CARE! vol ## [1] 2.506317e+12 # cubic microns  vol/1e9 ## [1] 2506.317

title: Mesh to mesh distances
text: Let’s just take quick detour see close approaches look like: Show close nodes query mesh Just query mesh
code: rgl::setupKnitr() nopen3d() plot3d(pv4b4, type='wire') plot3d(va6pn, col='red', type='wire') spheres3d(xyzmatrix(pv4b4)[kd$nn.dists<100,], col='green', r=500) nclear3d() plot3d(pv4b4, col=ifelse(kd$nn.dists<100, 'red', 'black')) plot3d(va6pn, col='grey') nclear3d() plot3d(pv4b4, col=ifelse(kd$nn.dists<100, 'red', 'black'), type='wire')

title: Mesh to mesh distances
text: range ways done, essentially number local minima distance field find. might also case one “patch” one neuron actually matches several patches neuron. However ’ll just try pick simpler approach example. Let’s take points threshold distance query neuron find geodesic distance (.e. distance along mesh surface) . need bit prep work , make graph representation mesh. Convert LHLN mesh representation Now can find geodesic distance selected nodes. Let’s try clustering distance matrix
code: #' Make an igraph representation of the edge network of a mesh object #' #' @param x A \code{mesh3d} object or an object for which an \code{as.mesh3d} #'   method is defined. As a convenience the first mesh object is extracted when #'   \code{x} is a \code{shapelist3d} object. #' @param ... additional arguments passed to \code{as.mesh3d} #' #' @return a \code{igraph} object whose vertices correspond to the vertices of the #'   original mesh object and whose edges have weights matching the edge lengths #'   in the mesh. #' @export mesh2graph <- function(x, ...) {   if(inherits(x, 'shapelist3d')) x=x[[1]]   if(inherits(x, 'neuronlist')) x=x[[1]]   if(!inherits(x, 'mesh3d')) x=as.mesh3d(x, ...)   if(nrow(x$it)!=3) stop("I only work for triangulat meshes right now")      # make the edge list   v1=x$it[1,]   v2=x$it[2,]   v3=x$it[3,]   el=rbind(cbind(v1,v2), cbind(v1,v3), cbind(v2,v3))   g=igraph::graph_from_edgelist(el, directed = FALSE)      # calculate lengths of each edge   xyz=xyzmatrix(x)   edgelengths = function(v1, v2) {     deltas=xyz[v1,,drop=F]-xyz[v2,,drop=F]     sqrt(rowSums(deltas^2))   }   weights=c(edgelengths(v1,v2), edgelengths(v1,v3), edgelengths(v2,v3))   igraph::E(g)$weight=weights   g } g=mesh2graph(pv4b4) dmat=igraph::distances(g, v=which(kd$nn.dists<100), to = which(kd$nn.dists<100)) dd=hclust(as.dist(dmat)) plot(dd, labels = F) # cut using a height relating to a separation of 3000nm groups=cutree(dd, h=3000) # sample randomises colours so that neighbouring clusters have different colours set.seed(42) groupcols=sample(rainbow(max(groups)))[groups]  nclear3d() spheres3d(xyzmatrix(pv4b4)[kd$nn.dists<100,], col=groupcols, rad=200) wire3d(pv4b4[[1]], col=ifelse(kd$nn.dists<100, 'red', 'black'), type='wire')

what: Support Functions for Analysis of FAFB EM Segmentation
title: Support Functions for Analysis of FAFB EM Segmentation
text: goal fafbseg provide support analysis segmented EM data, focussed full adult female brain (FAFB) dataset. Although support range data sources services, point principal target FlyWire automated segmentation. Legacy support also exists Google brain automatic segmentation FAFB data. fafbseg integrated NeuroAnatomy Toolbox suite (aka natverse) including elmr catmaid. fafbseg also one building block coconatfly provides unified simplified interface range Drosophila connectome datasets. actually recommend coconatfly good place start users since provides convenient access specific FlyWire data releases well powerful cross-connectome analyses requiring minimal configuration. See https://natverse.org/coconatfly/articles/getting-started.html details.

title: Support Functions for Analysis of FAFB EM Segmentation

title: Fetch flytable cell type information to a dataframe with flywire ids — add_celltype_info
text: x data.frame containing root ids neuronlist () idcol Optional character vector specifying column containing ids neurons cell type information provided. version Optional numeric CAVE version (see flywire_cave_query). special signalling value TRUE uses current default data dump returned flywire_connectome_data_version. suffix character suffix new columns (default value NULL implies suffix). table cell type information tables use (info brain, optic optic lobes ). ... additional arguments passed flytable_cell_types ids Flywire identifiers/query form understood flywire_ids unique Whether ensure rows contain unique identifiers. Default FALSE. TRUE duplicate rows returned warning.

what: Convert 3D x,y,z locations in brainmaps volumes to segmentation ids — brainmaps_xyz2id

text: Convert 3D x,y,z locations brainmaps volumes segmentation ids

title: Convert 3D x,y,z locations in brainmaps volumes to segmentation ids — brainmaps_xyz2id
code: brainmaps_xyz2id(   xyz,   volume = getOption("fafbseg.skeletonuri"),   rawcoords = FALSE,   rawvoxdims = c(8, 8, 40),   chunksize = getOption("fafbseg.brainmaps_xyz2id.chunksize", 200),   ... )

title: Convert 3D x,y,z locations in brainmaps volumes to segmentation ids — brainmaps_xyz2id
text: xyz N x 3 matrix points object containing vertex data compatible xyzmatrix. physical space (.e. nm) unless voxdims=NULL. volume character vector identifier string volume containing segmentation data - default uses value fafbseg.skeletonuri option. input can parsed brainmaps_volume acceptable. rawcoords Whether coordinates voxel indices (rawcoords=TRUE) physical units (nm, default). rawvoxdims implied voxel dimensions volume. rawcoords=TRUE used convert raw coordinates physical units. default value matches normal voxel size neuroglancer. rawvoxdims=NULL attempt made scale coordinates whatsoever. See details. chunksize send queries batches chunksize points. default chosen since brainmaps API can time points take long map (likely spread across brain). also maximum number points per call (10,000 recommended upper limit one point). ... Additional arguments passed brainmaps_fetch. can include setting retry argument >0. See Details Examples.

title: Convert 3D x,y,z locations in brainmaps volumes to segmentation ids — brainmaps_xyz2id
text: numeric vector Google segment ids

title: Convert 3D x,y,z locations in brainmaps volumes to segmentation ids — brainmaps_xyz2id
text: underlying brainmaps API expects raw coordinates .e.   voxel indices. slightly complicated fact different   segmentation, skeleton etc volumes may different associated voxel   dimensions. brainmaps_xyz2id automatically looks voxel   dimension. However may want pass raw coordinates   neuroglancer. generally associated resolution   image data e.g. skeletons may larger (coarser) voxel   size. convenience situation can set rawcoords=TRUE. problems requests failing sporadically, may helpful   know Google keep underlying data live may   spin-time. arbitrary timeout Google end (currently ~ 5s) batching nearby points helps Using chunksize argument retry argument passed   brainmaps_fetch can overcome issues. See   examples.

title: Convert 3D x,y,z locations in brainmaps volumes to segmentation ids — brainmaps_xyz2id
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Physical location in nm brainmaps_xyz2id(c(433368, 168208, 128480)) # Same location as displayed in neuroglancer brainmaps_xyz2id(c(54171, 21026, 3212), rawcoords=TRUE)  # Raw coodinates for the brainmaps volume in question - don't touch brainmaps_xyz2id(c(433368, 168208, 128480)/c(32,32,40), rawvoxdims=NULL)  library(elmr) # get a manually traced neuron (just keep first and only entry in neuronlist) dl4=read.neurons.catmaid('glomerulus DL4 right')[[1]] # map every node location to segmentation ids dl4.segs=brainmaps_xyz2id(dl4) # remove unmapped locations which get id 0 dl4.segs=setdiff(dl4.segs, 0) # read in corresponding skeletons dl4.skels=read_segments2(dl4.segs) # read in corresponding skeletons after including agglomeration merge groups dl4.allskels=read_segments2(find_merged_segments(dl4.segs))  ## retries / cache / chunksize issues # set small chunk size dl4.segs=brainmaps_xyz2id(dl4, chunksize=500) # use retries in case of failure dl4.segs=brainmaps_xyz2id(dl4, chunksize=500, retry=3) # cache successful requests (if you might need to repeat) dl4.segs=brainmaps_xyz2id(dl4, chunksize=500, retry=3, cache=TRUE) } # }

title: Choose or (temporarily) use a FAFB autosegmentation — choose_segmentation
text: released segmentation implies number global options.   package comes multiple different default scene urls specified via   choose_segmentation with_segmentation.   easiest way choose particular segmentation. can also pass   sample URL release argument. Nov 2020, "flywire31" default segmentation   package loads. specifies production (.e. progress) version   flywire dataset. need register flywire team   generate flywire token linked email used registration   access . Alternatively can also use   "public-flywire31" data release accompanying Dorkenwald et al   2023 Schlegel et al 2023 publications; still need token   (see flywire_set_token), registration required (  limitations use data new projects besides   citing two preprints). can also specify different sample URL via sampleurl   argument functions; remembered rest R   session. regularly use particular kind scene URL, can set   options(fafbseg.sampleurl) Rprofile file. need use built-custom segmentation URLs, recommend   specifying custom URL Rprofile file using   with_segmentation run code uses one built-  segmentations.

title: Convert between filenames and neuroglancer ids — fafbseg-ids
text: Segment ids unique integers. 8E8 current   skeletonisation seems ids can still > 2^31 (usually   .Machine$integer.max). Therefore stored R numeric   values bit64::integer64 values. segmentation keen skeletonised however usually results   multiple skeleton fragments written separate SWC   files: "named <segment id>.<fragment>.swc" segment id mapped onto zip file dividing divisor   discarding remainder. Peter Li's data release 2018-10-02 switched   1E5 1E6.

title: Convert between filenames and neuroglancer ids — fafbseg-ids
code: swc2segmentid("10001654273.1.swc") #> [1] 10001654273 swc2segmentid(sprintf("10001654273.%d.swc", 0:2), include.fragment=TRUE) #>          segment fragment #> [1,] 10001654273        0 #> [2,] 10001654273        1 #> [3,] 10001654273        2 if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # NB the default segmentation for fafbseg (flywire) no longer implies a local # collection of skeletons, wrap calls in with_segmentation with_segmentation("20190805", segmentid2zip(10001654273)) with_segmentation("20190805",   segmentid2zip(swc2segmentid("10001654273.1.swc"))) } # }

what: fafbseg: Support Functions for Analysis of FAFB EM Segmentation — fafbseg-package
title: fafbseg: Support Functions for Analysis of FAFB EM Segmentation — fafbseg-package
text: Functions read raw data formats produced Google electron microscopy segmentation tools displayed 'neuroglancer' allow basic 3D visualisation analysis.

title: fafbseg: Support Functions for Analysis of FAFB EM Segmentation — fafbseg-package
text: fafbseg.sampleurl optionally set sample Neuroglancer URL   modified point arbitrary locations   open_fafb_ngl. fafbseg.cave.datastack_name optionally set   datastack_name used CAVE system. Expert use .   Normally choose_segmentation looks . See   flywire_cave_query details. fafbseg.condaenv python environment use   miniconda. Defaults "r-reticulate", environment set   reticulate::install_miniconda. can set something   different like keep separate miniconda virtual   environment just fafbseg (expert use ). fafbseg.sqlitepath optional set location SQLite   tables used flywire_partners friends. fafbseg.cachedir location disk caches functions   including flywire_leaves unset package load,   set appropriate user folder using   rappdirs::user_data_dir. fafbseg.flcachesize maximum cache size bytes. Defaults   1.5 * 1024^3 unset. See flywire_leaves   details. fafbseg.flywire_roots.chunksize default   processing 100,000 rootids time. Set smaller queries time   / give "Request Entity Large" errors. Larger settings unlikely   much speed impact. See flywire_rootid   details. fafbseg.skelziproot set location folder   containing zipped versions skeletonised segmentations.   used read_segments, read_topn etc. fafbseg.skeletonuri brainmaps URI specifying remote   source used read.neurons.brainmaps   brainmaps_skeleton read neuronal skeletons. fafbseg.brainmaps_xyz2id.chunksize default   querying 4000 vertices time. Set smaller queries time   larger speed things . See brainmaps_xyz2id   details.

See examples seatable docs. convert Expert use : Whether allow Python seatable module process raw output database. principally debugging purposes. NB imposes requirement seatable_api >=2.4.0.

title: Fetch (memoised) flywire cell type information from flytable — flytable_cell_types
code: flytable_cell_types(   pattern = NULL,   version = NULL,   timestamp = NULL,   target = c("type", "cell_type", "hemibrain_type", "cell_class", "super_class",     "ito_lee_hemilineage", "malecns_type", "all"),   table = c("info", "optic", "both"),   transfer_hemibrain_type = c("extra", "none", "all"),   cache = TRUE,   use_static = NA )

title: Fetch (memoised) flywire cell type information from flytable — flytable_cell_types
text: pattern Optional character vector specifying pattern cell types must match SQL LIKE statement executed flytable_query. suffix _L _R can used restricted neurons annotated L R hemisphere. See examples. version optional CAVE materialisation version number. See flywire_cave_query details. Note also special signalling value TRUE implies latest locally available connectome dump. timestamp optional timestamp string POSIXct, interpreted UTC timezone specified. target character vector specifying flytable columns pattern match. special value type means either cell_type hemibrain_type match. special value means match cell_type, hemibrain_type, cell_class. table cell type information tables use (info brain, optic optic lobes ). transfer_hemibrain_type Whether transfer hemibrain_type column cell_type (default TRUE, see details) cache Whether cache results 5m (default TRUE since flytable query little expensive) use_static Whether use static cell type information (Schlegel et al)

title: Fetch (memoised) flywire cell type information from flytable — flytable_cell_types

title: Fetch (memoised) flywire cell type information from flytable — flytable_cell_types
text: transfer_hemibrain_type=TRUE, hemibrain_type   values transferred cell_type column   cell_type empty. seems SQL LIKE searches (e.g. containing % symbol)   work ito_lee_hemilineage column. can still search   exact matches use full regular expression queries (operate   downloading rows filtering machine). Static cell type information provided Schlegel et 2023. See   flywire_annotations   github repository. used default connection   pre-release Cambridge flytable available specified   options(fafbseg.use_static_celltypes=TRUE). Note presently   one materialisation version (630) supported static data.

what: Low level functions to access the flytable metadata service — flytable_login
title: Low level functions to access the flytable metadata service — flytable_login
text: flytable_login uses flytable user name email   log service. flytable_set_token obtain store permanent   seatable user-level API token. flytable_base returns base object (equivalent   mysql database) allows access one tables, logging   service necessary. returned base object give full access   Python   Base    API allowing range row/column manipulations. flytable_alltables lists tables across flytables   bases. flytable_columns returns name type regular   columns base well default R type. Private columns   _id included.

title: Low level functions to access the flytable metadata service — flytable_login
code: flytable_login(   url = "https://flytable.mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk/",   token = Sys.getenv("FLYTABLE_TOKEN", unset = NA_character_) )  flytable_set_token(user, pwd, url = "https://flytable.mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk/")  flytable_base(   table = NULL,   base_name = NULL,   workspace_id = NULL,   url = "https://flytable.mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk/",   cached = TRUE )  flytable_alltables(ac = NULL, cached = TRUE)  flytable_columns(table, base = NULL, cached = TRUE)

title: Low level functions to access the flytable metadata service — flytable_login
text: url Optional URL server token normally retrieved FLYTABLE_TOKEN environment variable. user, pwd flytable user password used flytable_set_token obtain token table Character vector specifying table foe want base object. base_name Character vector specifying base workspace_id numeric id specifying workspace. Advanced use since can normally figure base_name. cached Whether use cached version response available. Set FALSE know tables added renamed session. ac Optional account object returned flytables_login base Optional character vector naming seatable base (recommended) Base object returned flytable_base (expert use). default value NULL rely table long unique across flytable server.

title: Low level functions to access the flytable metadata service — flytable_login
text: flytable_login, Python   Account    object seatable api wrapped reticulate. flytable_base, Python   Base    object seatable api wrapped reticulate. data.frame containing base_name,   workspace_id, table name table _id. flytable_columns data.frame containing columns name,   type rtype

title: Low level functions to access the flytable metadata service — flytable_login
text: Besides initial setup (next paragraph), need use   lower level functions directly. Instead recommend higher level   functions flytable_query. order start using flytable, must get API token.   seem convenient way seatable web interface   can get one calling flytable_set_token flytable   user password. step. Thereafter   FLYTABLE_TOKEN environment variable set .Renviron   file. flytable_base use flytable API token log   service.

code: # identified location in FAFB14 p.fafb.nm <- cbind(477042, 284535, 90680) p.fafb.raw <- p.fafb.nm/c(4,4,40) # corresponding location in FlyWire p.flywire.raw <- cbind(118865, 71338, 2267) p.flywire.nm <- p.flywire.raw * c(4,4,40)  # check displacement flywire2fafb(p.flywire.nm)-p.fafb.nm #>      X  Y Z #> [1,] 3 -1 0  # check what happens when you apply the inverse fafb2flywire(p.fafb.nm)-p.flywire.nm #>       X Y Z #> [1,] -3 2 0  data("AV4b1", package='catmaid') set.seed(42) before=xyzmatrix(AV4b1)[sample(nvertices(AV4b1), size=2000), ] after=fafb2flywire(before) d=sqrt(rowSums((before-after)^2)) hist(d, br=20, main="FAFB14 - FlyWire Displacements", xlab="d /nm")   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ AV4b1.flywire <- xform_brain(AV4b1, reference="FlyWire", sample="FAFB14") plot3d(neuronlist(AV4b1.flywire, AV4b1)) } # }

FlyWire nucleus description
Nucleus version: 20210322

Nuclei in this table consist of center points (in nm), volume (in μm3), and bounding boxes (in nm).

The nucleus segmentation was generated by Shang Mu (smu@princeton.edu, Seung Lab at Princeton University) using a 2D convolutional neural network (CNN) and heuristic interpolations. The training data was assembled from annotations by Selden Koolman, Merlin Moore, Sarah Morejohn, Ben Silverman, Kyle Willie, Ryan Willie, Szi-chieh Yu and Shang Mu.

As this data was generated using a 2D, rather than 3D, neural network, defects are present in the detected nuclei, particularly where there are large defects in section alignment or a number of consecutive missing sections.

False positive fragments, nucleus fragments and partial nuclei are the most common type of defects. A simple, rudimentary method for cleaning up is to disregard small fragments by thresholding by segment size or by the z-dimension of the bounding boxes. A size threshold of 2000 voxels (0.08 μm3) was already applied in producing this segmentation.

A minimal number of nucleus merger instances have been observed, caused by section alignment defects or close nuclei appositions in certain non-neuronal cell clusters.

When using the nucleus annotations, please acknowledge Shang Mu and let him know about your use case.

We encourage making (and using) improvements to this data based on the information provided (for example, utilizing bounding box dimensions and/or the segmentation to find and merge incorrectly split partial nuclei), and such improvements should be discussed with Shang. Data derived solely from this work should be similarly made available on this platform at the time of use in any publication.

title: Query the FlyWire CAVE annotation system — flywire_cave_query
text: table name table (view, see views section) query datastack_name defaults value selected choose_segmentation "flywire_fafb_production" missing. See https://global.daf-apis.com/info/ options. version optional CAVE materialisation version number. See details examples. timestamp optional timestamp string POSIXct, interpreted UTC timezone specified. live Whether use live query mode, updates root ids current value (another timestamp provided). Values TRUE 1 select CAVE's Live mode, 2 selects Live live mode gives access even annotations part materialisation version. See section Live Live Live queries details. timetravel Whether interpret version/timestamp defined point past latest annotations sent back time, recalculating root ids necessary. filter_in_dict, filter_out_dict, filter_regex_dict Optional arguments consisting key value lists restrict returned rows (keeping matches filtering matches). Commonly used selected rows specific neurons. See examples CAVE documentation details. select_columns Either character vector naming columns python dict (required query involves multiple tables). offset 0-indexed row number, allows page long results (see section CAVE Row Limits caveats) limit whether limit number rows per query (NULL implies client side limit typically server side limit 500,000 rows). fetch_all_rows Whether fetch rows query exceeds limit (default FALSE). See section CAVE Row Limits caveats. ... Additional arguments query method. See examples details.

title: Query the FlyWire CAVE annotation system — flywire_cave_query
text: CAVE (Connectome Annotation Versioning Engine) provides shared   infrastructure number connectomics projects involving Sebastian   Seung's group Princeton collaborators Allen Institute.   backend system running servers Python client   end users. can find https://caveclient.readthedocs.io/ well   looking Python notebooks github repo   https://github.com/seung-lab/CAVEclient. annotation system shares authentication infrastructure rest   FlyWire API (see flywire_set_token).

title: Query the FlyWire CAVE annotation system — flywire_cave_query
text: CAVE concept   table snapshots identified integer materialization version   number. cases may wish query table defined version   number can avoid root_ids changing analysis.   calls also faster since root id updates required. Note however materialisation versions expire point   corresponding version database expunged. However still   possible find timestamp expired materialisation version.   flywire_cave_query automatically using   flywire_timestamp. circumstances queries   slower (quite possibly slower live query) since root ids   must recalculated match timestamp. CAVE's ability handle different timepoints key analysis   continually evolving segmentation frankly little difficult   users work . find things simplest either use long-term support (LTS) version, expire   630 version June 2023 public release 783 version   accompany published FlyWire papers. use latest CAVE version

title: Query the FlyWire CAVE annotation system — flywire_cave_query
text: CAVE versions segmentation   annotation tables shared version numbers. dataset stable,   using single version works well. However, found   arrangement ideal many situations, annotations often evolve   even though segmentation static. CAVE two options update annotations different point time: Live queries take contents table version   updates root ids match later timepoint (usually now). However   set annotations remains stuck selected version. starting   materialisation version chosen recent one preceding   requested timepoint. Live live queries (CAVE terminology, live=2) can return   state annotation table arbitrary timepoint. includes   annotations yet incorporated released   materialisation version. found different query modes cover use   cases. particular often want able travel backwards   time, taking current annotation table mapping root_ids onto   earlier state segmentation. can access functionality   setting timetravel argument. hood uses live   live query using now timestamp, followed translating root ids back   earlier state using associated supervoxel ids.

Furthermore filter_in,   filter_out queries using columns created SQL statement may   possible.

title: Query the FlyWire CAVE annotation system — flywire_cave_query
code: # \donttest{ # note use of limit to restrict the number of rows (must be integer) n10=flywire_cave_query(table = 'nuclei_v1', limit=10L) head(as.data.frame(n10)) #>     id             created superceded_id valid     volume pt_supervoxel_id #> 1 2338 2021-06-23 19:56:18            NA     t  0.2616115                0 #> 2 3078 2021-06-23 19:55:39            NA     t  4.1247949                0 #> 3 3292 2021-06-23 19:56:19            NA     t  0.2737357                0 #> 4 3502 2021-06-23 19:55:39            NA     t  6.7878502                0 #> 5 4404 2021-06-23 19:55:51            NA     t  0.8473395                0 #> 6 4446 2021-06-23 19:55:50            NA     t 58.8006195                0 #>   pt_root_id           pt_position     bb_start_position       bb_end_position #> 1          0 95520, 254368, 218600 94528, 253184, 218520 96384, 255776, 218680 #> 2          0 97472, 252352, 218040 96128, 248992, 217640 98944, 254720, 218600 #> 3          0 97280, 250784, 219320 96544, 249408, 219240 98080, 251744, 219520 #> 4          0 98304, 253376, 216480 96928, 250752, 215240 99936, 256000, 217240 #> 5          0 81280, 295968, 186680 80640, 294496, 186320 82048, 297600, 187440 #> 6          0 84128, 291584, 193400 81504, 288000, 190240 87104, 295904, 196280 # } if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ nuclei_v1=flywire_cave_query(table = 'nuclei_v1') points3d(xyzmatrix(nuclei_v1$pt_position))  library(elmr) # calculate signed distance to FAFB surface # NB this surface is not a perfect fit in the optic lobes nuclei_v1$d=pointsinside(xyzmatrix(nuclei_v1$pt_position), FAFB.surf,   rval = 'dist') points3d(xyzmatrix(nuclei_v1$pt_position),   col=matlab::jet.colors(20)[cut(nuclei_v1$d,20)]) plot3d(FAFB) } # } # Example of a query on a table if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # the Princeton (mostly) and Cambridge groups have tagged some bodies as # not a neuron - these are often glia. nans=flywire_cave_query('neuron_information_v2',   filter_in_dict = list(tag='not a neuron')) nrow(nans) table(nans$user_id) } # } if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ psp_351=flywire_cave_query(table = 'proofreading_status_public_v1',   version=351) # get the last listed materialisation version fcc=flywire_cave_client() lastv=tail(fcc$materialize$get_versions(), n=1) # pull that psp_last=flywire_cave_query(table = 'proofreading_status_public_v1',   version=lastv) } # }  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # timetravel query example # note use of allow_missing_lookups=T as not infrequently materialisation # can fail for a neuron cambridge_celltypes_v2.783 <- flywire_cave_query('cambridge_celltypes_v2', version = 783,   timetravel=TRUE, allow_missing_lookups=TRUE,   select_columns = list(cambridge_celltypes_v2=c("id", "tag", "pt_root_id", "pt_supervoxel_id")))  # querying by regex on a cell type in this table mbon012<- flywire_cave_query('cambridge_celltypes_v2', version = 783, timetravel=TRUE, allow_missing_lookups=TRUE, filter_regex_dict = c(tag='MBON0[12]')) } # }

title: Low level access to FlyWire data via Python cloudvolume module — flywire_cloudvolume
text: equivalent (Python): cloudvolume import CloudVolume vol =   CloudVolume('graphene://https://prodv1.flywire-daf.com/segmentation/table/fly_v31',    use_https=True) cache tries intelligent 1. generating new object every input parameter combination   (course need Python) 2. avoiding stale references checking Python currently   running returned CloudVolume object non-null. also   regenerates object every hour. Note reticulate package allows R/Python interaction binds   one Python session. Furthermore Python restarted without also   restarting R.

title: Access precomputed flywire connectivity data — flywire_connectome_data
text: type Character vector specifying kind data version Optional CAVE version. default value NULL uses latest data dump available unless options(fafbseg.flywire_connectome_data_version) set (can conveniently using flywire_connectome_data_version()). cached version NULL whether use cached value (lasting 1 hour) latest available version. ... Additional arguments passed arrow::open_dataset. set set=<number> passed argument specified data version used going forwards session default. achieved setting fafbseg.flywire_connectome_data_version option. set=NA specified option cleared. set=FALSE, latest version disk returned regardless value options("fafbseg.flywire_connectome_data_version")). See examples. default version return information available. Defaults NA indicate version information available.

title: Access precomputed flywire connectivity data — flywire_connectome_data

title: Access precomputed flywire connectivity data — flywire_connectome_data
text: depends precomputed data dumps prepared periodically Sven   Dorkenwald. can download public release version using function   download_flywire_release_data. can download versions Sven's Google drive folder. See   FlyWire    Slack message details URL. Two pieces information used determine version   queried. First value   options(fafbseg.flywire_connectome_data_version), second latest   available version connectivity dumps provided   flywire_connectome_data().

title: Access precomputed flywire connectivity data — flywire_connectome_data
code: # \donttest{ # latest available version/ syn=try(flywire_connectome_data('syn'), silent=TRUE) syn450=try(flywire_connectome_data('syn', version=450), silent=TRUE) if(!inherits(syn450, 'try-error')) { syn450 syn450$metadata  dl4ds <- syn450 %>%   filter(pre_pt_root_id==flywire_ids("DL4_adPN_L", version=450, integer64 = TRUE)) %>%   collect() }  # } if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # report active connectome dump version (defaults to most recent available) flywire_connectome_data_version()  # use the June 2023 public release version as the default flywire_connectome_data_version(set=630) # confirm this is the default flywire_connectome_data_version()  # check the latest version on disk flywire_connectome_data_version(set=FALSE)  # stop defaulting to specific version (therefore using the latest on disk) flywire_connectome_data_version(set=NA) flywire_connectome_data_version() } # }

title: Get predicted dense core vesicle locations in the flywire dataset — flywire_dcvs
text: rootid flywire rootid/rootids dataset DCV data set Stephan Gerhard access. 1.0 just antennal lobes FAFB. 2.0 first run whole brain. project project pull data. moment, one option DCV data. islatest logical, whether fetch latest root_id given IDs date. simplify logical, FALSE rootid separate set two data frames (one DCV positions, one neuron's synapses). Else, list two combined data frames returned. return One "parsed", "text" (raw JSON), "response" token Optional chunkedgraph token (otherwise default one current segmentation used). Use NA suppress use token. simplifyVector Whether use jsonlite::simplifyVector include_headers Whether include basic headers http request attributes parsed JSON object (default TRUE) parse.json=TRUE. OmitFailures logical, TRUE requests result 500 error dropped warning displayed error. cl cluster object created parallel::makeCluster, integer indicate number child-processes (integer values ignored Windows) parallel evaluations. ... additional arguments passed httr::{RETRY} function. may include config list named parameters etc.

text: logical vector length matching input. NA/0 input values   return NA output.

title: Check that one or more FlyWire root ids have not been further edited — flywire_islatest
text: call quite fast (think thousands ids per second).   current implementation also de-duplicates input automatically. can   pass vector containing duplicates unique ids   passed server. provide input integer64 data sent binary   form flywire server. can significant time saving   large queries (think 10000+). timestamp version provided, edits   time point considered. Note since August 2022   flywire_islatest return FALSE case rootid   created timestamp. Formerly returned   TRUE (see   seung-lab/PyChunkedGraph#412)

title: Check that one or more FlyWire root ids have not been further edited — flywire_islatest
code: # \donttest{ flywire_islatest("720575940621039145") #> [1] FALSE flywire_islatest(c("720575940619073968", "720575940637707136")) #> [1] FALSE FALSE  # check the first id up to a given timestamp # when was it created (= last modified) flywire_last_modified('720575940619073968') #> [1] "2020-12-02 11:43:01 UTC" # TRUE flywire_islatest('720575940619073968', timestamp = '2020-12-03 UTC') #> [1] TRUE # FALSE since it didn't exist flywire_islatest("720575940619073968", timestamp = "2020-12-01 UTC") #> [1] FALSE # } if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ latest=flywire_latestid("720575940619073968") flywire_islatest(latest)  # compare checking roots downstream of two large bilateral neurons blids=c("720575940619073968", "720575940637707136") blidsout=flywire_partners(blids) # 3.2 vs 4.7s in my test bench::mark(bin=flywire_islatest(blidsout$post_id),   str=flywire_islatest(as.character(blidsout$post_id))) } # }

text: Finds supervoxel ids input rootid maps   current rootid simple majority vote.

title: Find the most up to date FlyWire rootid for one or more input rootids — flywire_latestid
code: flywire_latestid(   rootid,   sample = 100L,   level = 2L,   timestamp = NULL,   version = NULL,   cloudvolume.url = NULL,   Verbose = FALSE,   method = c("auto", "leaves", "cave"),   ... )

title: Find the most up to date FlyWire rootid for one or more input rootids — flywire_latestid
text: rootid One ore FlyWire rootids defining segment (form interpretable ngl_segments) sample absolute fractional number supervoxel ids map rootids FALSE (see details). level resolution level chunked graph use calculating identity changes. integer 1 2. default (2, implying slightly larger supervoxels) considerably faster gives good results smallest fragments. See flywire_l2ids. timestamp optional timestamp string POSIXct, interpreted UTC timezone specified. version optional CAVE materialisation version number. See details examples. cloudvolume.url URL CloudVolume fetch segmentation image data. default value NULL chooses flywire production segmentation dataset. Verbose set TRUE prints information fraction method "cave" uses caveclient python module, generally faster, disadvantage disambiguate two options split. reason, method="auto" (default) currently chooses "leaves". NB method benefit persisent cache flywire_leaves second lookups much faster. ... Additional arguments passed flywire_leaves

title: Find the most up to date FlyWire rootid for one or more input rootids — flywire_latestid
text: character vector rootids. input 0 NA rootid   exist chunked graph, output 0.

title: Find the most up to date FlyWire rootid for one or more input rootids — flywire_latestid
text: default sample input rootids used since step   time consuming part. sample can defined fraction   (0<sample<1) absolute number. clamped actual   number supervoxels object. flywire_latestid precheck see input rootids   updated using flywire_islatest; precheck   fast (thousands neurons per second). ids   date processed identify new rootid. second   step slow (order 1-10 s per object). need regularly   set neurons, much better keep XYZ location   even better supervoxel id safe location neuron   primary branch point (typically cell body fibre joins rest   neuron). Note edits remove pieces starting neuron,   flywire_latestid return id largest resultant piece.

title: Find the most up to date FlyWire rootid for one or more input rootids — flywire_latestid
code: # \donttest{ # one of the neurons displayed in the sandbox with_segmentation('sandbox', flywire_latestid('720575940625602908')) #> [1] "720575940611617617" if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ with_segmentation('sandbox', flywire_latestid('720575940625602908', Verbose = T))  # check every supervoxel (slow for bigger neurons, but this KC is smallish) flywire_latestid('720575940616243077', sample=FALSE)  # update a neuroglancer URL with the most up to date segment ids # nb this is slow since it looks at all supervoxels - much more efficient to # store a single xyz location or supervoxel id u="https://ngl.flywire.ai/?json_url=https://globalv1.flywire-daf.com/nglstate/5695907068641280" ngl_segments(u) <- flywire_latestid(ngl_segments(u)) # open modified URL in your browser browseURL(u)  } # } # }

title: Find all the supervoxel (leaf) ids that are part of a FlyWire object — flywire_leaves
text: x One FlyWire segment ids cloudvolume.url URL CloudVolume fetch segmentation image data. default value NULL chooses flywire production segmentation dataset. integer64 Whether return ids integer64 type (default, compact little fragile) rather character (FALSE). mip mip level segmentation (expert use ) bbox bounding box within find supervoxels (default = NULL whole brain. Expert use .) cache Whether cache results flywire_leaves calls. See details. ... Additional arguments passed pbsapply eventually flywire_fetch method="flywire" cv$CloudVolume method="cloudvolume"

title: Find all the supervoxel (leaf) ids that are part of a FlyWire object — flywire_leaves
text: default repeated calls flywire_leaves cached   disk. functionality provided cachem package now used   memoise package. default cache expand 1.5GB   start pruning least recently used basis (LRU). 1.5GB might   store 10-20,000 results flywire_leaves calls depending   size corresponding neurons. Since root id can map hundreds thousands supervoxel ids,   space implications. order save space, results   stored compressed 64 bit integers (~30x smaller character   vectors). compression step add extra ~ 5   100x + faster cache hit. default compression based   suggested brotli library available, gzip otherwise. functionality memory cache top disk cache,   currently exposed disk read time appears small compared   time uncompressing overheads. cache can controlled two package options:  fafbseg.cachedir location disk. previously set,   set appropriate user folder package load using   rappdirs::user_data_dir. Note cache   function located inside folder called flywire_leaves. fafbseg.flcachesize maximum cache size bytes.   storage space exceeds results pruned using LRU algorithm.   Defaults 1.5 * 1024^3 unset. Note default configuration means cache shared   given user across R sessions. worth bearing mind possibility   race conditions multiple applications writing/pruning cache.   example fafbseg.flcachesize different values   different sessions, session smallest value start pruning   files disk session.

title: Find all the supervoxel (leaf) ids that are part of a FlyWire object — flywire_leaves

code: # \donttest{ if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ choose_segmentation("flywire") nx=xform_brain(elmr::dense_core_neurons, ref="FlyWire", sample="FAFB14") xyz = xyzmatrix(nx) ids = unique(flywire_xyz2id(xyz[sample(nrow(xyz),100),])) neurons = skeletor(ids, brain = elmr::FAFB14.surf) neurons.syns = flywire_neurons_add_synapses(neurons, transmitters = TRUE) neurons.syns[,]  # Plot in 3D library(catmaid) nopen3d() plot3d(neurons.syns, WithConnectors = TRUE)  # Axon-dendrite split library(hemibrainr) neurons.flow = flow_centrality(neurons.syns,   polypre = TRUE,   mode = "centrifugal") clear3d() plot3d_split(neurons.flow, WithConnectors = TRUE, transmitter = TRUE, radius = 1000, soma = 4000)  # Save .csv of synapses as FlyWire annotations flywire_synapse_annotations(ids[1], file="annotations1.csv", cleft.threshold=30)  # And similar, from a neuronlist syns = hemibrainr::hemibrain_extract_synapses(neurons.flow, .parallel = TRUE, OmitFailures = TRUE) flywire_synapse_annotations(syns, file="annotations2.csv", cleft.threshold=30)  } # } # }

title: Queries for information about flywire nuclei (helpful for finding somata) — flywire_nuclei
text: data.frame containing information nuclei including id nucleus id pt_position XYZ position centre nucleus.   always nm rawcoords=FALSE even remote table stores   raw (uncalibrated) voxel coordinates. comma separated string   rawcoords=TRUE since convenient pasting   applications. pt_supervoxel_id corresponding nucleus may missing   segmentation disrupted location nucleus e.g.   masking issues, missing sections etc. pt_root_id current root id (pt_position maps onto   segmentation.) volume volume cubic microns nucleus flywire_nearest_nuclei rawcoords=T   input output positions raw voxels. Note however distances   still calculated nm.

title: Find the input/output partners for a flywire neuron — flywire_partners
text: rootids Character vector specifying one flywire rootids. convenience flywire_partner_summary argument passed flywire_ids allowing pass data.frames, flywire URLs cell type queries. partners Whether fetch input output synapses . details Whether include additional details X Y Z location (default FALSE) roots Whether fetch flywire rootids partner neurons (default TRUE) reference character vector templatebrain object specifying reference template brain 3D coordinate information. default value "either" use natural reference space data source (FAFB14 SQLite tables, FlyWire spine service). cloudvolume.url segmentation source URL cloudvolume. Normally can ignore rely default segmentation chosen choose_segmentation method Whether use local SQLite database remote spine service synapse data. default auto uses local database available (45GB faster). Verbose Whether print status messages local path SQLite synapse data. Evaluated fafbseg:::local_or_google. Work progress. Default download data place ~/projects/JanFunke. ... Additional arguments passed pbsapply threshold flywire_partner_summary return partners greater number connections query neuron(s) (default 0 returns connections) remove_autapses flywire_partner_summary whether remove autapses (defaults TRUE) cleft.threshold threshold cleft score calculated Buhmann et al 2019 (default 0, used 30-100 increase specificity) summarise (never implemented.) Whether collapse results multiple query neurons single entry partner neuron. surf object defining 3D ROI inside presynaptic position must located. Can mesh3d object, object .mesh3d can handle including hxsurf boundingbox objects. See pointsinside details. version Integer materialisation version. special value 'latest' means recent materialisation according CAVE. timestamp timestamp normalise R Python timestamp UTC. special value 'now' means current time UTC. chunksize (expert use) number query neurons send per chunk cave client. Chunking requests speeds queries (sending neurons one time) still avoiding row number limits queries many neurons.

title: Find the input/output partners for a flywire neuron — flywire_partners
text: data.frame regtemplate attribute specifying   reference brain space xyz points. Columns vary slightly   depending whether data fetched spine/ITANNA local sqlite   database. obscure ones include:  prepost partners = "" column   present. given row (synapse), prepost=1 initial   query neuron downstream (postsynaptic) partner upstream. score came straight Buhmann et al supposed   indicate confidence score predicted synapse. cleft_score useful one later addition   Stephan Gerhard asks whether pre post synapses positioned   sensible distances side cleft defined separate neural   network Larissa Heinrich Stephan Saalfeld’s group.

title: Find the input/output partners for a flywire neuron — flywire_partners
text: FIXME behaviour partners well-defined. Note many duplicated connections raw output, false   autapses (.e. neuron connected ) false   positives. See Buhmann et al details ideas cleaning   results. Also note ids returned class integer64   flywire_partners one row   synapses/connection; flywire_partner_summary rows   report number connections pairs neurons, type   character. integer64 type compact   less robust base R type instead provided   bit64 package. R functions sapply strip   class integer64 vectors, treating doubles   completely different value. flywire_partners flywire_partner_summary   default report active connectivity state neurons. present   flywire_partner_summary allows time travel historic   materialisations using version timestamp arguments   (see flywire_timestamp details). support actually   depends cave backend (automatically selected   method='auto').

what: Find the root_id of a FlyWire segment / supervoxel. — flywire_rootid
title: Find the root_id of a FlyWire segment / supervoxel. — flywire_rootid
text: Find root_id FlyWire segment / supervoxel.

title: Find the root_id of a FlyWire segment / supervoxel. — flywire_rootid
code: flywire_rootid(   x,   method = c("auto", "cave", "cloudvolume", "flywire"),   integer64 = FALSE,   timestamp = NULL,   version = NULL,   cache = FALSE,   stop_layer = NULL,   cloudvolume.url = NULL,   ... )

title: Find the root_id of a FlyWire segment / supervoxel. — flywire_rootid
text: x One FlyWire segment ids method Whether use flywire API (slow python required) cave/cloudvolume (faster many input ids, requires python). "auto" (default) choose "cave" "cloudvolume" (order) available flywire otherwise. integer64 Whether return ids integer64 type (compact little fragile) rather character (default FALSE). timestamp optional timestamp string POSIXct, interpreted UTC timezone specified. version optional CAVE materialisation version number. See details examples. cache Whether cache supervoxel id -> rootid mappings. Default FALSE works version timestamp available. Note cache held memory therefore regenerated R session. stop_layer layer chunked graph stop . default NULL equivalent layer 1 full root id. Coarser layer 2 IDs can useful intermediate operations. cloudvolume.url URL CloudVolume fetch segmentation image data. default value NULL chooses flywire production segmentation dataset. ... Additional arguments passed pbsapply eventually flywire_fetch method="flywire" cv$CloudVolume method="cloudvolume"

title: Find the root_id of a FlyWire segment / supervoxel. — flywire_rootid
text: vector root ids character vectors.

title: Find the root_id of a FlyWire segment / supervoxel. — flywire_rootid
text: main purpose function convert supervoxel   current root id whole segment. segment id updated   due editing, calling original segment id still return   segment id (although calling supervoxel return new   segment id). wish find latest root id, can use   flywire_latestid, fairly slow (think 1 second per   neuron). However general best select XYZ location defining   neuron interest, associated supervoxel id store , since   can rapidly looked flywire_xyz2id   flywire_rootid. three methods. "flywire" simpler   much slower many supervoxels since id requires separate http   request. "cave" method much faster can process hundreds   ids per second. order avoid sending many requests one go   (limit post message size), id lookups chunked   maximum 50,000 lookups single call. can modified passing   chunksize argument setting   fafbseg.flywire_roots.chunksize option. Set smaller   queries time / give "Request Entity Large" errors. Larger settings   unlikely much speed impact. cloudvolume method default August 2022. uses   server endpoint tests 2x slower cave (still   much faster method='flywire')

title: Find the root_id of a FlyWire segment / supervoxel. — flywire_rootid

code: # \donttest{ ts=flywire_timestamp(349) ts #> [1] "2022-04-18 08:10:00 UTC" # As a unix timestamp (number of seconds since 00:00 on 1970-01-01) as.numeric(ts) #> [1] 1650269400 tsp=flywire_timestamp(349, convert=FALSE) # should be same as the numeric timestamp above tsp$timestamp() #> [1] 1650269400  flywire_timestamp(timestamp="2022-08-28 17:04:49 UTC") #> [1] "2022-08-28 17:04:49 UTC"  # nb this will return the current time *in UTC* regardless of your timezone flywire_timestamp(timestamp="now") #> [1] "2024-09-07 10:36:13 UTC" # } if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # same but gives a warning flywire_timestamp(timestamp="2022-08-28 17:04:49") } # }

what: Find FlyWire root or supervoxel (leaf) ids for XYZ locations — flywire_xyz2id
title: Find FlyWire root or supervoxel (leaf) ids for XYZ locations — flywire_xyz2id
text: Find FlyWire root supervoxel (leaf) ids XYZ locations

title: Find FlyWire root or supervoxel (leaf) ids for XYZ locations — flywire_xyz2id
code: flywire_xyz2id(   xyz,   rawcoords = FALSE,   voxdims = c(4, 4, 40),   cloudvolume.url = NULL,   root = TRUE,   timestamp = NULL,   version = NULL,   stop_layer = NULL,   integer64 = FALSE,   fast_root = TRUE,   method = c("auto", "cloudvolume", "spine"),   ... )

title: Find FlyWire root or supervoxel (leaf) ids for XYZ locations — flywire_xyz2id
text: xyz One xyz locations Nx3 matrix form compatible xyzmatrix including neuron mesh3d surface objects. rawcoords whether input values raw voxel indices nm voxdims voxel dimensions nm used convert raw coordinates. cloudvolume.url URL CloudVolume fetch segmentation image data. default value NULL chooses flywire production segmentation dataset. root Whether return root id whole segment rather supervoxel id. timestamp optional timestamp string POSIXct, interpreted UTC timezone specified. version optional CAVE materialisation version number. See details examples. stop_layer layer chunked graph stop . default NULL equivalent layer 1 full root id. Coarser layer 2 IDs can useful intermediate operations. integer64 Whether return ids integer64 type (compact little fragile) rather character (default FALSE). fast_root Whether use fast two-step look-procedure finding roots. strongly recommended alternative approach retained validation purposes. method Whether use spine transform-service API cloudvolume lookup. "auto" presently synonym "spine". ... additional arguments passed pbapply looking multiple positions.

title: Find FlyWire root or supervoxel (leaf) ids for XYZ locations — flywire_xyz2id
text: character vector segment ids, NA lookup fails.

title: Find FlyWire root or supervoxel (leaf) ids for XYZ locations — flywire_xyz2id
text: root ids define whole neuron segmented object. supervoxel ids   correspond small group voxels assumed must belong   object. supervoxel ids change given segmentation,   whereas root ids change every time neuron edited. stable way   refer FlyWire neuron choose nice safe location   arbour (recommend major branch point) store location   supervoxel id. can rapidly map supervoxel id current root id   using flywire_rootid. November 2020, default approach look supervoxel ids   3D point using   spine   transform-service API. order 100x faster mapping via   cloudvolume (since must make single web request every point)   Eric Perlman optimised layout underlying data rapid   mapping. Note using slower cloudvolume method (may still required   volumes fast lookup via spine available)   finding supervoxel given XYZ location order 3x faster   finding root id agglomeration super voxels   given object. Perhaps less intuitively, want look many root   ids, actually quicker flywire_xyz2id(,root=F) followed   flywire_rootid since function can look many root   ids single call ChunkedGraph server. happens   setting fast_root=TRUE, default.

title: Find FlyWire root or supervoxel (leaf) ids for XYZ locations — flywire_xyz2id
code: # \donttest{ if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # example based on defining some sample points from real neurons # sample dataset from FAFB catmaid n=elmr::dense_core_neurons[[1]] set.seed(42) ss=sample(nvertices(n), size=10) # first convert FAF14 points to FlyWire coordinate space nx=xform_brain(elmr::dense_core_neurons[[1]], ref="FlyWire", sample="FAFB14") pts=xyzmatrix(nx)[ss,] } # }  # for simplicity just define those same sample points directly pts = matrix( c(428910.52, 110629.64, 174800, 410201.86, 110419.1, 180400,   337136, 129926.28, 189280, 349981.85, 136041.53, 199280, 398361.74,   110731.26, 182640, 382789.26, 118987.04, 189920, 358033.92, 171592.92,   143960, 360990.48, 140277.42, 201400, 376258.06, 125201.51, 194400,   331370.31, 128338.58, 181760), ncol = 3, byrow = TRUE, dimnames = list(NULL, c("X", "Y", "Z")) )  #' # Fast and simple appoach to find ids in one (user-facing) step flywire_xyz2id(pts) #>  [1] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #>  [4] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #>  [7] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #> [10] "720575940634984800"   ## illustrate what's happening under the hood  # find the ids for the selected xyz locations # NB fast_root=FALSE was the default behaviour until Nov 2020 flywire_xyz2id(pts, fast_root=FALSE, method="cloudvolume") #>  [1] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #>  [4] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #>  [7] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #> [10] "720575940634984800"  # we can also find the supervoxels - much faster svids=flywire_xyz2id(pts, root=FALSE)  # now look up the root ids - very fast with method="cloudvolume", the default flywire_rootid(svids) #>  [1] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #>  [4] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #>  [7] "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" "720575940634984800" #> [10] "720575940634984800" # }

what: Graph representation of the agglomeration (merge) between raw segments — make_merge_graph

title: Add colours to the neuroglancer scene — ngl_add_colours
code: fw_url=with_segmentation('flywire31', getOption('fafbseg.sampleurl')) ngl_add_colours(fw_url, colours=c("720575940614404544"="red")) #> neuroglancer scene with 2 layers and 2 segments (of which 2 shown) #>                                 name                    type visible nsegs #> 1                   Production-image                   image    TRUE     0 #> 2 Production-segmentation_with_graph segmentation_with_graph    TRUE     2 #>   nhidden #> 1       0 #> 2       0 #>                                                                        source #> 1 precomputed://gs://microns-seunglab/drosophila_v0/alignment/image_rechunked #> 2          graphene://https://prod.flywire-daf.com/segmentation/table/fly_v31  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # colour all neurons in the URL on the clipboard red. # Then convert back to URL and open in default browser browseURL(as.character(ngl_add_colours(clipr::read_clip(), col="red")))  # Let's colour neurons from these 3 scenes in red, green and blue u1="https://ngl.flywire.ai/?json_url=https://globalv1.flywire-daf.com/nglstate/5695474417795072" u2="https://ngl.flywire.ai/?json_url=https://globalv1.flywire-daf.com/nglstate/5198787572137984" u3="https://ngl.flywire.ai/?json_url=https://globalv1.flywire-daf.com/nglstate/5673953041317888" # sequentially build up a data.frame with the colour information # note that col will be recycled to the same length as the number of segments colourdf=data.frame(ids=ngl_segments(u1), col='red') colourdf=rbind(colourdf, data.frame(ids=ngl_segments(u2), col='green')) colourdf=rbind(colourdf, data.frame(ids=ngl_segments(u3), col='blue')) # apply that to the first URL sc=ngl_add_colours(u1, colourdf) browseURL(as.character(sc)) } # }

text: ann annotation dataframe (see details) object containing 3D vertices xyzmatrix can successfully extract points. rawcoords Whether points provided raw (voxel) coordinates calibrated (nm) positions. default NA try infer based coordinate values see details limitations. colpal function named character vector colours used set colour layer. Colours specified name hex format.
